page.title: 02HURSLEY AND AMPFIELD
page.content: Two thirds of Ampfield is forest, { "Ampfield}Wood",covering one thousand and four acres.The timber grown sells from Â£7 to Â£40 a cubic metre.The trees are both deciduous and coniferous and the wood is an important {"natural"}habitat with animal and plant life. The village of Ampfield and the smaller village of Knapp are situated on the {B3090 road} from Romsey to Hursley. {Animals }like deer,foxes, rabbits,mice,badgers and grey squirrels live and enjoy the safety of the wood.The gravel rides are a perfect place for{butterflies}and many are seen there including the bright yellow brimstone, the common holly blue, the delicate orange tip, the streaked white admiral and the strongly coloured peacock.
